FACE TO FACE
The Famous Face Guessing Game
Le Jeu Des Portraits-Énigmes

boardgame.name: Le Mystere des Masques
boardgame.description:
The year is 1791 and France continues its headlong slide into a state of anarchy and terror. As the starving French people riot openly in the blood-stained streets, leaders of the country's various rival factions continue to quarrel and fight in their attempts to seize outright control.

Meanwhile, following their desperate failed attempt to flee the country, the deeply unpopular King Louis 16th and his equally despised wife, Marie Antoinette, have been taken to the Bastille fortress, where they are now being held under guard, "for their own safety".

In a brave attempt to inject a small degree of normality back into the royal couple's lives, Cardinal Richelieu decides to continue as planned, with the Masked Ball he was intending to hold in honor of the King’s 40th birthday - albeit on a much smaller scale, with just the jail’s four current residents, and each of their guests, in attendance.

However, with just an hour to go until the party begins, Richelieu is horrified to discover King's lifeless body lying slumped across his dressing room table, having been poisoned with some form of deadly toxin!
Confusion soon replaces shock, however, when a second ‘living and breathing’ Louis then appears, identical to the first, and claims that he is the real king, and that the corpse is obviously just a ridiculous impostor!

With the future of France at stake, Richelieu realizes he must enlist the help of all those attending the ball, if he is to catch his killer and unravel this mystery, before news of the terrible events escapes, and a panic takes hold of the city!

boardgame.name: Solo Dungeon Bash
boardgame.description:
This game is for anyone who is on their own and fancying a Dungeon Bash. All you need are these rules, a piece of paper (preferably of the graph variety), a pen and a bunch of six sided dice.

The dungeon is made up of a grid of squares, 9 squares wide and 10 rows deep. There are additional start and end squares in the middle column.

The objective is to move from the Start square up through the levels of the Dungeon and into the End square where the Big Bad Boss Monster lives and to finally defeat it. Failure to defeat the Big Bad Boss Monster means you have lost.

Solo Dungeon Bash is a solitaire dungeon crawl. This print-and-play game is available at
http://blackdogofdoom.blogspot.com/2010/09/solo-dungeon-bash...

Online version is available at https://games.sprogram.com.ua/en/games/solo-dungeon-bash (free to play)

boardgame.name: Centre Rock
boardgame.description:
A game of territory, defense, and pushing the other guy around! Your foot soldiers will stop at nothing to gain control of The Rock for you, but you must manage shifting alliances, plan ahead while striking now, and catch good fortune to be victorious...

Centre Rock is an abstract strategy game in which 2--4 players vie for control of The Rock. Each player commands a squad consisting of a striker (pikeman), two archers, and two melee units. Movement is based on hexes, and each unit type may attack a particular pattern of surrounding cells. Games take 45--90 minutes.

Centre Rock is also a freely downloadable DIY game. Full rules, game board, and pieces are available for download on the RocketShip Games website along with detailed instructions for constructing your own copy.

boardgame.name: Nid De Cigogne
Storchennest
Stork's Nest
boardgame.description:
This game claims to be a 19th century Bohemian game replicating the problem people have with storks constructing their huge nests on top of chimneys.

The game consists of a 3-piece wooden house (house, roof, and chimney), and 60 sticks.

The sticks are divided evenly between the players, who take turns placing them in a stack on the chimney.

If a player knocks any sticks off of the nest, they must take all of the fallen sticks and add them to their supply.

The first player to run out of sticks is the winner.

Comes with instructions in English, French, and German.

La Belle Alliance
The Battle of Waterloo

The Battle of Waterloo, fought on 18 June 1815, was Napoleon Bonaparte's last battle. His defeat put a final end to his rule as Emperor of France. While the campaign hung in the balance for most of its duration, the decisive battle became the Battle of Waterloo. Allied forces, under Wellington, withstood a final French attack, and counter-attacked while the Prussians, arriving in force, broke through on Napoleon's right flank.

The Lost Opportunity

Grouchy was ordered to pursue the Prussians and prevent them from joining Wellington. boardgame.name: Quatre Bras: Stalemate on the Brussels Road
boardgame.description:
Quatre Bras
Stalemate on the Brussels Road

The crossroads of Quatre-Bras was of strategic importance because the side which controlled it could move south-eastward along the Nivelles-Namur road towards the French and Prussian armies at the Battle of Ligny. If Wellington's Anglo-Allied army could combine with the Prussians, the combined force would be larger than Napoleon's. Napoleon's strategy had been to cross the border into the Netherlands without alerting the Coalition and drive a wedge between their forces and subsequently to defeat the Prussians before turning on the Anglo-Allied army. Although the coalition commanders did have an overview of French pre-war movements, Napoleon's strategy was initially very successful.

The battle cost Ney 4,000 men to Wellington's 4,800. Although a tactical draw, the allies had been unable to send forces to the aid of the Prussians at the Battle of Ligny. Wellington's Anglo-Allied army, upon learning of the Prussian defeat, was forced to retreat north along the Brussels road further away from the Prussians, who retreated north-east towards Wavre.

There has been much debate of what would have happened if d'Erlon's I Corps had engaged at either Ligny or Quatre Bras. As he did not, Napoleon chose to follow Wellington with the bulk of his forces, and two days later met his destiny at Waterloo.

Quatre Bras is part of the Napoleon's Last Battles Quadrigame. It was also sold separately as a folio game.

Folio version includes rules, a 17" x 22" map and 100 counters.

boardgame.name: Ligny: Incomplete Victory
boardgame.description:
Ligny
Incomplete Victory

Napoleon's strategy was to cross the border in secret and attack the Allied armies before they could combine and outnumber his army. If he could engage them separately, then his army would outnumber theirs in individual engagements. To that end, he had sent Ney's 2nd Corps and 3rd Cavalry Corps to block the Allied army at the crossroads of Quatre Bras on the same day, so that it could not proceed down the Nivelles-Namur road to bolster the right of the Prussian position.

The Prussians had deployed along the Ligny Brook. They held all the farmhouses and a good defensive position, with most of their advance forces under cover. In fact the Prussian three army corps' positions were so good, that Napoleon at first was deceived into thinking there was only one army corps. However, Blücher had overstretched his left flank, and exposed his right to French artillery.

Included in the Napoleon's Last Battles Quadrigame. It was sold separately as a folio game.

Folio version includes rules, a 17" x 22" map and 100 counters.

boardgame.name: Kachina
boardgame.description:
Kachina is a tactical tile game based on the traditions of the Hopi Native American tribe. Each round you place one of your limited number of Kachina tiles, trying to dominate the largest possible area of the board.

In the Hopi tradition, the world is ruled by kachinas (or spirits) of many different types. Children of the tribe learn about these different spirits through the use of Kachina dolls. To illustrate the tension of different spirits in the world, the tribal elders create games of kachinas vying for dominance. Will the Eagle soar above the Ogre? Will the Clown humiliate the Chief to nothingness? Or maybe the Sun God outshines all in its radiance?

You'll have to plan ahead and use your Kachina tiles to best effect to outscore your opponents in this very strategic tile game. You build the board as you go, so no two games are alike. Each type of tile has a different ability. Can you predict what your fellow players will do and guide your Kachina to dominance?

boardgame.name: Caporetto, 1917: Catastrophe for Italy
boardgame.description:
Caporetto, 1917
Catastrophe for Italy

By the standards of the Great War, Caporetto was a remarkable battle. Within a month, the Austro-Germans inflicted over 300,000 Italian casualties at a loss to themselves of only 100,000, and had shifted the front over 100 miles. But they fell short of a decisive victory.

Caporetto recreates this spectacular offensive. Modifications to the Great War in the East Standard Rules account for infiltration, naval fire support, changes of command, heroic "last ditch" leadership, and much more. The game poses different problems for each Player, with the Austro-German player impelled to push his advance as fast and as far as possible and the Italian Player forced to retreat, often in the face of certain losses to his rear-guard units, in order to rebuild his shattered line. But despite the inherent imbalance of forces, the game is tensely balanced.

Included in the The Great War in the East: Four World War 1 Battles Quadrigame.
Folio edition contains Standard rules, Special rules, 17" x 21" map and 200 counters.

boardgame.name: The Brusilov Offensive: Imperial Russia's Last Campaign, 1916
boardgame.description:
The Brusilov Offensive
Imperial Russia's Last Campaign, 1916

In mid-May 1916, the Allies were faced with two crises. At Verdun the French army was gradually being bled to death, and in Trentino, the Italian army was rapidly nearing its breaking point. As in August 1914, the Allies sent out a call of au secours to the Russians.

The Russians responded on 4 June with an offensive along the entire line of General Brusilov's Southwest Front. This operation resulted in the capture of some 150,000 square miles of territory, inflicted losses of over 3/4 million, and force the Central Powers to weaken their offensives. As great as it was, however, the Brusilov Offensive was not the strategically decisive victory the Russians needed to stave off internal collapse. In the game the Russian player must break through the Central Powers line and encircle masses of enemy troops, while the Central Powers Player must make careful withdrawals and timely counterattacks. For both Players, the game is demanding and requires coherent planning and careful execution.

boardgame.name: Von Hindenburg in Poland: The Warsaw-Lodz Campaign, 1914
boardgame.description:
Von Hindenberg in Poland
The Warsaw-Lodz Campaign, 1914

In the wake of Russian successes in Galicia, Grand Duke Nicholas plotted an invasion to the mineral-rich German province of Silesia. To forestall this, von Hindenberg transferred four German corps from Prussia to the southwest corner of Poland and launched an offensive toward Warsaw. By 12 October, they had driven the Russians back to the Vistula, just south of Warsaw, but there, outnumbered and over-extended, they ran out of steam.

Von Hindenberg in Poland simulates the intense back-and-forth struggle that began 16 October, with von Hindenberg's retreat from the Vistula. Over the course of the ensuing six weeks, both sides surged forward and back, east and west, alternately threatening the other with potentially disastrous encirclements. Special rules cover the effects of inferior Russian intelligence (hidden movement for the Germans), the combined effects of poor Russian logistical capacities and German scorched-earth policies.

Included in the The Great War in the East: Four World War 1 Battles Quadrigame.
Folio edition contains Standard rules, Special rules, 17" x 21" map and 200 counters.

boardgame.name: Serbia/Galicia: Austria-Hungary at War, 1914
boardgame.description:
Serbia/Galicia
Austria-Hungary at War, 1914

Prior to the outbreak of the Great War, the Chief-of-Staff of the Hapsburg Army, Count Conrad von Hotzendorff, had declared that the Empire's forces were not strong enough to undertake simultaneous full-scale offensives in both Poland and the Balkans. Nevertheless, in the Autumn of 1914, this is what he attempted.

Serbia/Galicia includes a dual map, which illustrates both major fronts on which the Austro-Hungarians were deployed in 1914. The Austro-Serbian border, from Belgrade to Montenegro, is shown on half the map, while the majority of Galicia, including Lemberg and the crucial Prezmysl-fortress complex, is on the other half. On the first map area, the Austrian forces must try to make headway against the under-equipped but ferocious Serbs, while on the other, the Russians attempt to make up for the disasters in Prussia by overrunning as much of Galicia as possible. Special rules cover Serbian supply constraints, Austrian river-monitors, and the transfer of Austrian troops.

boardgame.name: Sim Serim
boardgame.description:
Sim Serim is an abstract game designed for two players (or two teams consisting of two players each).

This game by Heinrich Glumpler is played on a square wooden board with 7×7 fields where the fields in two corners are replaced by icons representing the players ("moon" and "sun"). The players sit at the corner of the board showing their respective icon.

The game is played in rounds. At the start of each round players reveal 1 to 4 stones of their color simultaneously. The number of revealed stones decides the order in which both players place their stones on the board.

The player do not have a lot of choice when placing their stones since new stones must be placed in the current row - meaning: the row where the last stone was placed in the previous round. Only after the current row is filled completely the active player may select a new row by placing a stone at the edge of the board.

It is much more important to foresee the order in which stones are placed since the resulting patterns on the board will decide the number of points each player gets at the end of the game.

The special flavour of the game results from the fact, that the scoring takes place in the vertical and horizontal lines of the board - running in a 45 degree angle to the rows where the stones were placed.

Players earn points for each magic wand, meaning each combination of exactly three stones lying in line and adjacent to each other. The tricky part is, that a player will lose points for any magic wand that is too long - having more than three stones.

boardgame.name: Burger Joint
Burger vs Pizza
boardgame.description:
In this two-player game, each player runs a chain of fast-food joints: one specializes in burgers and the other in pizzas. As each expands, they take on some of the menu items of the other in order to compete for customers. Later, each can open family restaurants and even high-class dining establishments. The most successful chain will win in the end!

Players alternate turns as the active player. Each turn consists of five actions.
1. Production. Where a player draws cubes from a bag (Here the cubes represent different resources.)
2. Players trade and use special abilities to convert cubes into more helpful combinations.
3. Spend their resources to build up their fast food empire (by improving their restaurants to diners or by increasing their publicity)
4. Calculating their current score – first player to 12 victory points wins.
5. Discard unused and excess goods in preparation to start the next round.

boardgame.name: Battle Box: WWII (Europe)
boardgame.description:
A simple and fast boardgame contained within a box. One page of rules, fantastic graphics on the map, 20 plastic miniatures, dice, and hours of simple war gaming fun.

This game is not designed to simulate, it is a game. Fathers and sons, fathers and daughters, and even mothers with children will love the simplicity and speed (most games last less than 30 minutes). Old school gamers will also love it as a quick fix game.

It is 1940. Players choose the Allies or the Axis to play. The board has preset armies for both side that begin on the board. A game last 15 turns unless a clear winner before then. Some turns have preset first phase players, some the players dice for initiative. On those turns player get to go first automatically, they also receive reinforcements. Essentially, the allies must hold out until mid-game or they are going to loose. The Germans must win quick, or the allies will eventually overwhelm them. Hey! Just like the real war...

The game uses very simple mechanics for movement and combat, and it is in no way a simulation. The idea is to provide a "beer and pretzels" game for those who don't have time to play a more involved wargame.

The concept behind the Battle Box series is simple and fun: Play when you can. The game is perfect for introducing young would be generals to wargaming, as even as early as 10 years old the rules and concepts are easily grasped.

Available at www.flamingmonkeygames.com

boardgame.name: The Champion Game of Baseball
boardgame.description:
The Champion Game of Baseball was published by the Proctor Amusement Company of North Cambridge, Massachusetts in 1889. It consists of a baseball field printed on the bottom of the box with a metal spinner in the middle, a rules sheet, and an envelope with nine blue and nine red cardboard disks.

There is not a lot of strategy in this early game - each team uses the spinner on its turn to bat. Most of the results are either outs or hits (spaces for single, double, triple and home run), but there also are spaces for strikes, balls and base on balls. It is therefore possible but unlikely to get three strikes or four balls. There is one space for a foul ball, and any spinner stopping on a line is considered a foul as well.

The one strategic option open to the batting team is whether to have base runners try to steal. In this event, the stealing team spins again, but uses an outer ring where the results are divided between "out", "safe" or "sacrifice" (where the runner advances but the current batter is out). An out result always picks off the lead runner.

boardgame.name: Dictator
boardgame.description:
There were a few more real life dictators in the world when this game was published in 1939. Very little information can be found about this board game.

Update - The game comes with many lead minatures (8 Aviators representing each player, 12 submarines, 8 Battleships and 16 aeroplanes). Definitely the king of game play pieces by weight alone. The map contains a circle of spaces surrounded by 3 territories which hold the game's key resources- Manchukuo (Iron), Dutch East Indies (Oil) & Ukraine (Wheat). The game play spaces have actions (like collect $4 million or capture enemy plane) or consequences (sub sunk) and even political events (revolt, coup or treaty - which are separate cards).

The center of the board represents the armament factory and all the minatures begin there to be bought by the player as they build up their forces. The players move around the circle by the roll of the dice collecting and losing money, armaments and political cards to be used in the game. The goal of the game is to collect military forces so that you can control the 3 territories (1 at a time or if you are strong enough, all at once). The players move military units into and out of the territories on their turns, conquering weaker opponents (and taking their units). If you have the required military units in the territory and you have earned a propaganda card (by landing on the right space) you gain the resource of that territory. Having all 3 resources wins the game.

boardgame.name: Pass The Ewe
boardgame.description:
There are five suits in this game: The 12 royal cards (J, Q, K) of all four traditional suits make one suit; they don’t count for their normal suits. The remaining cards in the other suits (A to 10 in spades, hearts, clubs, and diamonds) make the other four suits.

If you’re starting a hand, you must play one or more cards of only one suit (S, H, C, D, royals). Play passes to your left.

When play passes to you, you may pass or play. If you pass, play passes to your left. If you play, you must play a homogeneous set of cards that beats what was most recently played. The rank of the card you play is irrelevant, but the number of cards you play and their suit is relevant.

Suit Ranking:
Hearts beat spades and clubs. Clubs beat hearts and diamonds. Diamonds beat clubs and royals. Royals beat diamonds and spades. Spades beat royals and hearts.

If the most recent play was one heart, you can play one club, or one spade, or two hearts. You can not play more than what you need to beat what was played; you can’t play three or more hearts or two or more clubs or spades.

Short play example:
Alice starts a hand by playing two clubs. Bob plays three clubs. Cathy passes. Dan plays three diamonds. Alice passes. Bob passes. Cathy plays three royals. Dan plays four royals. Alice plays four diamonds. Bob plays four clubs. Cathy plays four hearts. Dan passes. Alice plays five hearts. Bob, Cathy, and Dan all pass and Alice takes the hand.

If play passes back to you and you were the last player to play, you get the ewe totem and all of the cards played go face-down into your Wool Pile. You get a one-point bonus to your score. The hand is over.

If all players have cards left in hand, the player to the left of the player with the ewe starts the next hand. If at least one player is out of cards the round is over. If you have cards in hand at the end of a round, you lose one point for every card in your hand. If you have the ewe at the end of a round, you get a two-point bonus to your score.

If the round is over, count the number of cards in your Wool Pile and have the scorekeeper add that to your score. If one or more players have 100 points or more, the game is over. If the game is not over, collect and shuffle all of the cards.

If you have the ewe at the end of the game, you get a 5-point bonus to your score.

boardgame.name: uPSet
boardgame.description:
From the Publishers Website:
uPSet is a thrilling and unpredictable combination of chance and strategy where one throw of the dice or one play of a card can turn the game around and the winner of the game is in doubt until the very last second.
Using dice, cards, an interactive scoresheet and poker-style chips (uPcentS), uPSet takes only a few minutes to learn but every game is a different roller-coaster ride of fun and excitement. uPSet strikes that perfect balance between rewarding skilled and strategic play and introducing the element of luck to make sure that everyone has a chance to win and victory is never a sure thing.

Inspired by games played in Labrador fishing villages, Upset includes specialty dice, cards, chips, and interactive scorecards that shape play by determining who gets the cards and when. The object of the game is to score points with the dice (10,000 to win) and strategically use the Upset cards to beat your opponent. Players strategize not only on how and when they play their cards, but also how to get or avoid getting the cards. However, the special dice contain letters as well as numbers and if someone rolls the word "Upset," then everyone else, no matter how close they are to winning, must restart from scratch.

Home Page: http://www.playupset.com/

Der Markt der Azteken
El mercado azteca
El Mercado de Tlatelolco
boardgame.description:
This is the first known game designed by Spanish gamer Victor Melo.

Winner of the "I Board Games Creation Contest" at Granollers (Barcelona), El Mercado Azteca (The aztec market) is becoming popular inside Spanish gamers' community. The contest is the result of the impulse and work of a great well known Spanish designer: Oriol Comas i Coma.

The game is almost a pure German Game:

Small and easy set of rules
Fast games
Attractive theme not too present in the game flow


It has also an easy Print & Play prototype that you can play just by printing some counters and using some extra components from other games or even from your kitchen (beans,...).

About the theme:
The game tries to represent the great pre-Columbian market of Tlatelolco (Mexico). The player is a merchant trying to get goods (4 different types) from the sellers while trying to increase their value. To increase your chances of buying you'll need to spend your influence points to adapt the market to your needs. The board is modular and changes every turn. The players can move the board pieces, this being an important part of the strategy.

This game is winner of the 2007 Concurs Ciutat de Granollers de creació de jocs.

boardgame.name: Tagalong
Tagalong Cowboy Joe
Tagalong Joe
boardgame.description:
The object of this abstract game is to place five tokens of one color in a row in any direction on a special 12 by 12 game board grid or to force your opponent into three "traps" -- the twenty red squares on the game board.

The four-player version of the game involves team play while the three-player version involves one player alternatively playing against the other two.

100 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation.

Other bonus scoring include the following:
100 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation with 10 tokens or less.
50 points for completing a five-in-a-row formation within the pink square.
50 points for forcing your opponent into 3 traps.
20 points for forcing your opponent into 2 traps.
10 points for forcing your opponent into 1 trap.

This game was manufactured by Wales Games Systems, Inc., a division of Wales-Strippit Corporation in North Tonawanda, New York, USA. It was later slightly modified to fit in with the western theme of Wales Game Systems' other games, having a cowboy hat added to the drawing of Joe and becoming "Tagalong Cowboy Joe," a "64-32 Ranch Game."

boardgame.name: The Kanji Game
boardgame.description:
From the back of the box: Kanji symbols are an ancient Chinese method of writing that was introduced to Japan almost 2,000 years ago. Kanji symbols are visual representations of words, word fragments or entire ideas. While there are as many as 50,000 Kanji in existence, Japanese people use only about 2,000 today.

For 2 to 4 players ages 5 and up.

THE OBJECT: To be the player to collect the most points by the end of the round.

HOW TO PLAY: The Kanji game has three levels of play. Set up the double-sided playing board according to the level of play you choose. Divide the 176 cards into four card groups: GO, 1-2-3, Kanji and Dot. Give the arrow a spin and let the race begin.

A card is drawn and players must think and react quickly as they learn how to speak, read and visualize Kanji symbols. The first player to find the card's exact match on the playing board (matching color and symbol) and to place his or her pawn on the match wins the card. Did you draw a Kanji Samurai card? Now you must draw the Kanji symbol, the final step in putting it all together!

Whoever has the most points at the end of the round wins that game! Sounds easy? Think again!

What are you learning? Not only are players learning the elements of a foreign language, they are also building the skills necessary to improve mathematics, memory, concentration and visual relationships while actively being motivated to think, respond and learn!

boardgame.name: Disney Bursdagsspillet
boardgame.description:
In Bursdagsspillet (The Birthday Game), the players are invited to Donald Duck's birthday party and must play a round of the Hat Game before proceeding to the cake.

The players throw the dice to determine which color of the hat to move. A hat can be put on top of one single other hat, be freed on special balloon squares, or being swapped if the special die shows the party hat. When a single or double hat passes the finish line, one point goes to the player playing the color of the hat on the top.

Contents:

- Game board
- 16 hats in 4 colors
- 1 regular die
- 1 special die with colors

boardgame.description:
In Først og Sist (First and last), players try to find words starting with a given letter and ending with any letter shown on the game board. If a player successfully finds a word, he or she takes the first letter, and moves the last letter to the top of the game board, becoming the starting letter of the next word, which the next player must find.

If a player cannot find a word, the starting letter is turned around, only to become a new letter, or a joker.

boardgame.name: Boe!
Meuh !
Moo!
Muh!
boardgame.description:
A children's game which can be played two different ways. In both games 12 tiles are set in a square and each player places their cow on the first square. The objective is to get your cow around the square. The colored milk bottles are set up in the middle of the square.

In the version called The Cow Goes Moo, each player takes turns rolling the color die and trying to knock over up to five bottles, but not more than five or they will lose their turn. The player gets to move their cow one space for each fallen bottle which matches the color rolled on the die.

In the Big Cow Poker version, before each roll, every player secretly chooses a color card. The roller knocks down up to five milk bottles and each player gets to move a number of spaces equal to the number of fallen bottles which match their card.

boardgame.name: Gespensterschule
L'alphabet fantomatique
Spokenschool
Spooky Spelling
boardgame.description:
Three childrens games can be played with this set of letter stamps, "ghost" tins and "ghost" word cards.

In Little Ghostly Alphabet the objective is to stamp two words. The stamps are put in the tins. Then each player gets a ghost card with a word on it. The words are in multiple languages, including English. Each turn a player selects a tin, then stamps any letters which are in their word. The letters must be stamped in order.

The Word Searchers is a variation on Hangman, using the stamps.

In G as Ghost, the stamps are again put in the tins. Each player chooses a tin, then uses a stamp inside to either start a new word or extend a word that is already started. Players must announce the word they are thinking of. Other players can either stamp the letters in that word or switch to another word as long as the letters already stamped match the new word. Only three words can be started at a time. The game ends after five words are completed.

boardgame.name: Geni Junior
boardgame.description:
Junior Geni is a children's edition of the very popular Norwegian trivia game Geni, with simplified rules and different question categories.

The goal of this game is to answer one question correctly from each of the four categories, and then answer questions from two given categories, moving to the center of the board. The first player to reach the center is the winner.

Originally released in 1988, the game has been re-released with new questions and categories in 1995, 1998, 2000, 2003 and 2007.

Each game typically contains 250 cards, all with questions from all four categories, including 'Books and music', 'Our world', 'Nature', 'Entertainment', 'Science', varying from the different editions.

boardgame.name: Khans and Kings
boardgame.description:
From the Rules:

"General. Khans and Kings (K&K) is the first expansion to the Chevauchee game. Neither game is intended to be a rigorous historical exercise, but more to provide a fun game with some sense of correct period flavor and feel. In this case, K&K adds an “Eastern” (for lack of a more specific term) series of decks, along with a modified “Western” opponent to face them. The Eastern forces are representative of Steppe Warrior armies, most closely modeling Mongols, but also representative of their inheritors as well (Golden Horde, Blue Horde, White Horde, Timurids, Tartars, Cumans, and so forth)."

The game is available free for download at:

http://games.groups.yahoo.com/group/Dubious-designs/

boardgame.name: Free Agency
boardgame.description:
Made by LDS (Latter Day Saints) Game Factory in Placerville, CA. I don't have the instructions, but it looks as though players go around the board -- and off into little side trips like Talents, Leisure, Career, Church. Family and Education -- to gather Blessings but to avoid Trespasses. According to the score sheets, you tally each, plus add the number of side trips made to the Blessing column and it looks like the highest Blessing score wins.

Knowledge cards get you Blessings or Trespasses. Free Agency cards quote verses from LDS scripture. Corner spaces are significant: Go on a Mission or to the Tree of Life; these are the good squares. The bad ones are Temptation and Sin City. It looks like Sin City is like Monopoly's Jail square. You must roll to get out and the longer it takes, the more Trespasses you get.

boardgame.name: Caterpillar Race
Raupen-Wettlauf
boardgame.description:
(From the box)

Create your own unique multi-colour caterpillar and race to victory in this exciting game.

Aim of the game: To be the first player to cross the finish line with your caterpillar.

1. Build your multi-colour 6 segment caterpillar.
2. Set up the finish line and decide the starting point of the race.
3. Take it in turns to roll the dice. Move your caterpillar segments (starting from the back) one in front of the other until the coloured segment at the front matches the colour on the dice. Place the head on the front segment.
4. If the colour on the die matches the colour of the front segment of your caterpillar, you miss a go. If this happens you can place a barrier in front of your opponent to slow them down.
5. Your opponent must now move around the barrier in order to reach the finish line.
6. The winning caterpillar is the one to cross the finish line first.

"The search for fame and glory has lured many MechWarriors to the gladiatorial splendor of the Solaris VII arenas. Legends like Danai Liao-Centrella and Yulri Wolf earned their notoriety by competing and triumphing in the no-holds-barred, ’Mech™-on-’Mech duels of the planet’s combative environment. WizKids has taken the Mech element from Mechwarrior: Age of Destruction and confined it within a small arena. Implementing hex based maps with lots of terrain and a simultaneous heat + damage system, Solaris VII is fast paced and easy to get into. The Mech's maintain cross game compatibility so you can bring in your existing collection to the Solaris game world. boardgame.name: Il Buono, il Brutto e il Munchkin
Dobry, Zły i Munchkin
The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin
A Jó, a Rossz és a Munchkin

Хороший, плохой, манчкин
boardgame.description:
Oh, give me a home where the Jackalopes roam
And the Dudes and the Buckaroos play,
I'll slay and I'll loot, give the monsters the boot,
And the dice are not loaded, no way.

The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin opens a whole new frontier - the Wild West! Forget dragons and goblins - Jackalopes and Davy Croc have just as much treasure. Those plains may seem wide open, but there's lots of monsters to kill, and lots of stuff to take.

Become a Cowboy with a Twenty-Gallon Hat, or an Indian on a Catamount. Fight Wild Bill Hiccup, the Killer Jalapeno, and a Barber Shop Quartet. Take The Annual Bath for an extra level. Or just pal around with your sidekick the Greenhorn, until you sacrifice him to distract a monster.

The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin is the next stand-alone game in the award-winning Munchkin line. Steve Jackson (I) and John Kovalic have teamed up again to put puns to paper like no one else can. Head 'em up and move 'em out, and get ready to wander the Grim Roper into somebody else's combat and make him "Rootin' Tootin'" for +10...

Beneath the Waves (BtW) is a board-game but started as a floor-top game played entirely at shows. The game is set in a fictional world around 1870. Each player commands one or more steam punk submarines with the goal to sink the opposing side's submarines or fulfill a certain goal/mission.

Then you have to decide the movement of the submarine, trying to outsmart your opponents move. The game is played by two or more players. The players belong to one side or the other, Germany or the Confederate States of America (CSA). Each side has one or more submarines, three or four for a normal game.

boardgame.name: Check-o
boardgame.description:
From the Instruction folder:

"CHECK-O is an exciting new game, designed to entertain every member of the family. Two, three or four people can play."

"Action takes place on a board with traditional checker-squares on it, separated so that red squares touch red squares at diagonal corners and similarly, white squares touch white squares at diagonal corners. Moves by players are made diagonally."

"The object of the game is to capture opponents' men by leap-frogging over them until the checkers of only one player remain."

"It will be noted that there is a big square area in the center of the board. Wings extend in four directions giving the playing area the shape of a cross."

"CHECK-O is a direct descendant of the ancient game of Checkers, devised over 5,000 years ago by the Egyptian Pharoahs (sic), so history tells us."

"When the Roman soldiers conquered Egypt, they took home many souvenirs of their exploits in North Africa. Among these was the game of Checkers. Even in ancient times, moves were made in the same way - diagonally across the board - and each player faced his opponent with twelve men."

"CHECK-O, though similar to Checkers, is faster-moving and gives more opportunity for strategy. This is especially true in CHECK-O DOUBLES when each player must out-plan and out-think three opponents who are coming towards him from three different directions."

boardgame.name: Chuggedy Chug Game
boardgame.description:
A simple train game for children in which a player spins a spinner and then moves his train down a track. Special spaces on the track can force the child to blow his whistle or to lose a turn, possible destroying a deeply developed strategy.

The game is significant for its theme. Pictured prominently on the box is the ventriloquist Paul Winchell and two of his wooden dummies. In reality, Winchell and the dummies have nothing to do with the game - their names simply appear on the board. But Winchell was at the height of his popularity when the game was released, so he name and image were used as makerting tools.

On a side not, Paul Winchell also did the voice of Tigger in the Winnie-the-Pooh movies.

(English translation from on-line translator and re-worded a bit by me:)Each player receives two pawns of the same color. The challenge is to bring both pawns to the end space. I presume this to be the giant electrical plug at the end of space 80. The youngest player begins. A player advances as many spaces as a roll of the die. No moving backwards. If you roll a six, you may roll again. Only one pawn at a time on each number. Elimination is permitted. If you land on an orange number, you must immediately follow the instructions printed on the side of the board. Whoever gets both his pawns into the end space with exact roll of the die is the winner. Only one pawn at a time on each number. Elimination is permitted.

boardgame.name: Vex
boardgame.description:
Equipment consists of eighty-one wooden tiles. The tiles represent three complete alphabets and three wild cards. One player draws three tiles and composes a word that uses those three letters of not more that nine letters. The other player has to guess the word. Guessing the word within six tries scores the guessing player two points. Guessing the word within eleven tries scores the guessing player one point. Stumping the guessing player scores the other player two points. The first team to twelve points wins.

When more than two play, they play as two teams.

Vex was named in the Games Magazine Games 100 of 1998.

boardgame.name: Harpoon, The Real Whale Hunt Game
boardgame.description: The gameboard is a thirty-six by thirty-six grid that represents a large body of water. The grid is divided into four quadrants. The players start with a small whale boat that is placed inside an individual’s factory ship. Each player places one’s own factory ship at an individual start space at the edge of one’s own quadrant. One of the whales is placed on one the four spaces in the center of the gameboard. Players, in turn, move their factory ships according to the number indicated on the spinner. If spinner points to a picture of a whale, then the whale moves according the number on its spinner. A player must separate the whale boat from the factory ship when the whale and the factory ship are in the same quadrant. Whale boats have their own spinner and they move slower that do the factory ships. When the whale boat and the whale are on the same space, the whale has been harpooned and the player scores a point for killing the whale. The whale boat must be moved back into the factory boat and another whale is brought into play. The last whale brought into play is white and it is worth two points. The player with the most points is the winner.

boardgame.name: Mimikk
boardgame.description:
Mimikk (Mimicry) is a game where one player makes faces while the others try to recognize the grimace.

Each turn, a player draws a face card, and the other close their eyes while the first player try and mimic the face on the card (with help from the mirror).

When the player knocks the table, the other players can look at his or her face and try to find the corresponding face on the board.

Contents:

Game board
32 face cards
One mirror
Six pawns

boardgame.name: Matte-Kryss
boardgame.description:
Mattekryss (Math scrabble) is a Scrabble-like game, only with numbers.

Each player always has seven tiles on his stands and try and make computations on the board. Each tile is placed next to two other tiles and must be the result of a computation (addition, subtraction, division or multiplication) of these two tiles. Some squares are pink, and restricts the type of operation to perform.

Contents:

Game board
106 tiles with numbers
Four stands

boardgame.name: Pharo-Myd
Pharomyd
boardgame.description:
PHAROMYD is played on a triangular board using 16 four-sided "pyramids" (tetrahedrons) - each side has a different marker colour/symbol on it. Players move pieces with the aim of preventing other players from moving, but can only move pieces with their symbol showing. Each piece can be moved by 3 players - the three sides showing - but players can also convert pieces so that their own symbol shows.

A move consists of rolling a "pyramid" in one of 3 directions, tipping it along an edge onto a new face. There are patterns to form - such as sandwiching a "pyramid" between two other "pyramids" with identical faces showing toward each other.

Any player unable to move on their turn is eliminated and the game ends when only 1 player is left in the game.
